Expectation1: Avoid gossiping or speaking negatively about others
Situation1: An acquaintance makes a negative comment about a colleague's recent work performance.
Situation2: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Story:
I sat in the break room, stirring my coffee, when Sam leaned in and whispered, “Did you see how badly Mark messed up the report? I don’t know how he still has a job.” I felt a familiar discomfort. As an acquaintance, I knew I should avoid gossiping or speaking negatively about others, but Sam’s expectant eyes waited for my agreement or at least a reaction. I didn’t want to seem unfriendly or judgmental, but I also didn’t want to betray my own values.

At the same time, my phone buzzed with a message from my friends: “We’re booking our Hajj tickets tonight! Are you in?” My heart ached. I had been saving for years, setting aside money for this sacred journey, but the cost was high, and I worried about my finances. The pressure from my friends was strong—they expected me to join them this year, and I longed to fulfill this pillar of my faith.

Caught between the urge to fit in with my colleagues and the spiritual pull of Hajj, I felt the weight of conflicting expectations pressing down on me, unsure which path to take.
